verses.text: Early on the first day of the week, while it was still dark, Mary Magdalene went to the tomb and saw that the stone had been removed from the entrance.
verses.comment: Mary Magdalene's arrival while still dark highlights her devotion and the unexpected nature of the resurrection. All four Gospels mention women at the tomb, emphasizing the significance of eyewitnesses to the resurrection.

verses.text: She ran and went to Simon Peter and to the other disciple, the one whom Jesus loved, and said to them, 'They have taken the Lord out of the tomb, and we do not know where they have laid him.'
verses.comment: Mary immediately seeks out Peter and the beloved disciple, underlining their leadership roles among the apostles.

verses.text: So Peter and the other disciple set out and went toward the tomb.
verses.comment: Peter and the beloved disciple act quickly, demonstrating urgency and commitment to Jesus.

verses.text: They were both running together, but the other disciple outran Peter and reached the tomb first.
verses.comment: The beloved disciple’s younger age or greater zeal might explain why he arrives first, but he defers to Peter in entering.

verses.text: Stooping and looking in, he saw the linen cloths lying there, but he did not go in.
verses.comment: The presence of grave clothes suggests the body was not stolen, pointing to something supernatural.

verses.text: Then Simon Peter arrived following him, and he went into the tomb. He saw the linen cloths lying there,
verses.comment: Peter’s boldness in entering first reflects his leadership among the apostles, which will echo in the book of Acts.

verses.text: and the face cloth, which had been on Jesus’ head, not lying with the linen cloths but folded separately in a place by itself.
verses.comment: The careful arrangement of the grave clothes shows order, not theft, indicating a purposeful act—an early witness to the resurrection’s fact.

verses.text: Then the other disciple, who had arrived at the tomb first, also went in, and he saw and believed.
verses.comment: Seeing the grave clothes and empty tomb provokes faith—a moment highlighting personal witness' importance and a possible spiritual insight.

verses.text: For as yet they did not understand the Scripture, that he must rise from the dead.
verses.comment: The connection to Old Testament prophecies reinforces Jesus’ resurrection as a fulfillment of Scripture and divine necessity.

verses.text: Then the disciples went back to their homes.
verses.comment: Disciples went home in confusion—anticipating the unfolding revelation of Jesus’ resurrection.

verses.text: But Mary stood outside the tomb, weeping. As she wept, she stooped to look into the tomb.
verses.comment: Mary’s tears reveal love and grief, echoing the theme of personal encounter with Christ in sorrow.

verses.text: She saw two angels in white, sitting where the body of Jesus had lain, one at the head and one at the feet.
verses.comment: The angels’ presence signifies the sacredness of the resurrection, reminiscent of the cherubim at the Ark (Exodus 25:18-19).

verses.text: They said to her, 'Woman, why are you weeping?' She said to them, 'They have taken away my Lord, and I do not know where they have laid him.'
verses.comment: Mary’s reference as ‘my Lord’ conveys deep personal faith and love for Jesus, not mere respect for a teacher.

verses.text: When she had said this, she turned around and saw Jesus standing, but she did not realize that it was Jesus.
verses.comment: Mary’s inability to recognize Jesus may connect to the transformed, glorified body of Christ and people’s gradual recognition of spiritual realities.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, 'Woman, why are you weeping? Whom are you seeking?' Supposing him to be the gardener, she said to him, 'Sir, if you have carried him away, tell me where you have laid him, and I will take him.'
verses.comment: Notice Christ’s gentle approach; the reference to ‘gardener’ may allude to Eden, pointing to Jesus as the New Adam (Romans 5:14-17).

verses.text: Jesus said to her, 'Mary.' She turned and said to him in Aramaic, 'Rabboni!' (which means Teacher).
verses.comment: Mary’s recognition upon hearing her name deepens the emphasis on personal encounter and Christ’s shepherd-like knowledge of His followers (John 10:3).

verses.text: Jesus said to her, 'Do not hold on to me, for I have not yet ascended to the Father. But go to my brothers and say to them, “I am ascending to my Father and your Father, to my God and your God.”'
verses.comment: Jesus’s words distinguish the unique relationship with the Father, highlighting his divinity and the believers’ adoption. The command to proclaim points to a mission to share the apostolic witness.

verses.text: Mary Magdalene went and announced to the disciples, 'I have seen the Lord,' and that he had said these things to her.
verses.comment: Mary is the first messenger of the risen Christ, highlighting the importance of personal testimony and the role of authoritative witness.

verses.text: On the evening of that day, the first day of the week, the doors being locked where the disciples were, for fear of the Jewish authorities, Jesus came and stood among them and said, 'Peace be with you.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ sudden appearance emphasizes his glorified body. His greeting echoes messianic peace (Isaiah 52:7) and points to the foundation for forgiveness and reconciliation (Romans 5:1).

verses.text: When he had said this, he showed them his hands and his side. Then the disciples rejoiced when they saw the Lord.
verses.comment: The wounds bear witness to his real death and bodily resurrection. The rejoicing echoes fulfillment of Jesus’ promises (John 16:20).

verses.text: Jesus said to them again, 'Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, so I send you.'
verses.comment: Jesus commissions the apostles, linking their mission directly to his own—a foundational passage for the teaching authority handed down through apostolic succession.

verses.text: And when he had said this, he breathed on them and said to them, 'Receive the Holy Spirit.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ breathing recalls God’s impartation of life to Adam, signifying a new creation. This event prefigures Pentecost and the gift of the Spirit—especially for the foundational ministry of the apostles.

verses.text: If you forgive the sins of any, they are forgiven them; if you withhold forgiveness from any, it is withheld.
verses.comment: Jesus gives his apostles authority to forgive sins, a clear mandate for sacramental confession—foreshadowing the ongoing ministry of reconciliation in the church.

verses.text: Now Thomas, one of the Twelve, called the Twin, was not with them when Jesus came.
verses.comment: Thomas’ absence prepares the ground for a special revelation of Christ’s risen body, emphasizing community and faith.

verses.text: So the other disciples told him, 'We have seen the Lord.' But he said to them, 'Unless I see in his hands the mark of the nails, and put my finger into the mark of the nails, and place my hand into his side, I will never believe.'
verses.comment: Thomas demands physical proof, looking for the reality of Jesus’ crucifixion and resurrection—exemplifying the struggle between doubt and faith.

verses.text: Eight days later, his disciples were inside again, and Thomas was with them. Although the doors were locked, Jesus came and stood among them and said, 'Peace be with you.'
verses.comment: The detail of ‘eight days later’ echoes the rhythm of worship and the significance of the Lord’s Day in Christian tradition.

verses.text: Then he said to Thomas, 'Put your finger here, and see my hands; and put out your hand, and place it in my side. Do not be faithless, but believe.'
verses.comment: Jesus offers physical evidence, patient with Thomas’ doubt, and invites him into genuine faith—the wounds symbolize our redemption.

verses.text: Thomas answered him, 'My Lord and my God!'
verses.comment: Thomas’ declaration is a direct and explicit acknowledgment of Jesus’ divinity—a statement central to high Christology and foundational for authentic Christian worship.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Have you believed because you have seen me? Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed.'
verses.comment: The blessing on those who believe without seeing foreshadows the ongoing life of faith and the value of the church’s teaching authority for future generations.

verses.text: Now Jesus did many other signs in the presence of the disciples, which are not written in this book.
verses.comment: The Gospel contains selected signs; the reference to unwritten deeds points to the larger body of apostolic teaching entrusted to the church community.

verses.text: But these are written so that you may believe that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of God, and that by believing you may have life in his name.
verses.comment: The purpose of the Gospel is clear: to foster saving faith in Christ’s divinity and messianic role, affirming both the necessity of belief and participation in Christ’s life through his name.
